 http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/NEWS/World/Rest_of_World/Conservatives_in_Kansas_lose_fight_against_Darwinism/articleshow/1614628.cms
 
 
Conservatives in Kansas lose fight against Darwinism
 [ 15 Feb, 2007 0154hrs ISTREUTERS ]
 
 
 TOPEKA, (KANSAS): The Kansas board of education on Tuesday threw out science standards deemed hostile to evolution, undoing the work of Christian conservatives in the ongoing battle over what to teach US public school students about the origins of life. 
 
 The board in the central US state voted 6-4 to replace them with teaching standards that mirror the mainstream in science education and eliminate criticisms of evolutionary theory. 
 
 "I'm glad we've taken this step. If we are going to have a well-educated populace, this is important," said board member Sue Gamble. 
 
 Similar efforts to weaken the teaching of evolution in public schools have occurred throughout the US including Pennsylvania, Michigan, Kentucky and Georgia. 
 
 But Kansas has been in the forefront of the debate since 1999, when the board voted to sharply reduce the emphasis of evolution in science instruction. A public backlash ultimately led to a reversal of that revision. 
 
 The new standards, set to take effect immediately, replace those put in place in 2005 by a conservative majority of the board who challenged the validity of evolution and called it incompatible with religious doctrine. 
 
 It is the fourth time in eight years that science standards have been rewritten in Kansas. 
 
 "I think it actually curtails the ability of students to learn and to think," said conservative board member Steve Abrams of the latest revision. 
 
 Kansas' struggles have been widely lampooned and were depicted in a documentary film entitled Flock of Dodos.

Last time I checked most state boards merely set the guidelines, whether or not they are followed is something entirely different. Still the fact that you have a board of education spouting such ridiculousness is pretty damn amusing.

 
 The way it works in Kansas, the state board of education sets the guidelines and sends them out to all the school districts where they sit in a box in a closet somewhere. During much of the time when all this idiocy was going on, I was ON the local school board and had never once opened one of those books. We all knew they existed, and nearly half of us knew where ours were, it was just not something that anybody generally cares to look at. I would be shocked if you could find me 10 kids in the entire state who have ever read the state school boards definition of "science" or their guidelines. It is just not something that comes up. 
 
 IMO, that is why this issue came up in kansas. Our state school board here has VERY little power or control, so nobody really pays attention to them. When the first set of changes occured, there was a lag of about 6 months before anybody even realized it and then it was somebody from the media.
 
 
You got numbers? I'm curious.

 
 There is the ever popular "smartest state" report that places kansas at #15 in the nation. It can be found at http://www.morganquitno.com/edrank.htm
 
 A lot of kansas educators take exception to that report because it factors in things that may not be related. For example, Kansas kids score in the top 5 states in ALL testing categories, BUT, we score 38th in spending per pupil. We score poorly in teacher salaries (28), and do not have teachers on our school boards (conflict of interest). All those factors count against us, as well as several others. Then you have new jersey and vermont, where the kids apparently can't take a test, and where their average SAT scores may be confused with a shoe size, and they score in the top 5 because they spend a LOT more than kansas. A lot of people argue that they penalize states for efficiency in their education system. 
 
 If you want the most comprehensive report out there, go to www.alec.org and request a copy of their "report card for education". I think it is free, and it breaks down the states by several categories. It is what I always used to figure out how good a job our system was doing.

 I know somebody who is a tin temple kook. He used to work for me and was a pretty good machinist, if not the sharpest pencil in the box. He is constantly sending me religously oriented junk Email. I have noticed a couple of things. First, most of the Emails he sends turn out to be BS (snopes). Second, a continuing theme in many of them tends to be that there are a large number of christians, or a large number of people who believe in god, in the US. 
 
 I think that those messages are largely an appeal to common sense (which we all know is actually an appeal to ignorance). He essentially seems to be trying to say "a lot of people agree with me, therefore I am right". I don't think that he recognizes that most of those people do NOT agree with him, most of them would view him as the locals do...as a kook from the tin temple.
 
 I was raised catholic and I remember in the classes leading up to confirmation was one of the priests at our parish explaining the bible and how it should be interpeted. He said that to argue for the infalibility of the bible is to argue against in the existance of god. In the dark ages (and for quite a while following) information was rather scarce and hard to come by and when you DID learn something, it was often unreliable. During those times, when ignorance was the natural order of things simply due to a lack of reliable information, a literalist interpetation of the bible was possible by even reasonable people. Today, that is not the case. Essentially he argued that if your faith includes something as nonsensical as a lteralist interpetation of the bible, or the belief that the bible is infallable (when there are clearly some major contradictions there), Then a belief in god is nearly impossible since neither of those (litrealist interpetation or infallability) can possible be considered accurate by any reasonable person. Faith built on a lie is not faith.

jyoshu

To be fair, in point of fact no one actually KNOWS that the Gilgamesh epic is older than the Noah epic. We don't know how old the Noah story is at all--the writer(s) of Genesis very well may have been putting into writing a story that had been around awhile. The only 2 things we know here is that the materials on which the writing of the Gilgamesh epic predate anything we've found revealing the Noah event, and that the Noah story would be SET later if you go by the generations written about in Genesis (which is very vague at times). Neither really proves factually that the Gilgamesh account predates the Noah account.
obvious_child

To be fair, in point of fact no one actually KNOWS that the Gilgamesh epic is older than the Noah epic.

 
 The Gilgamesh Epic is the Noah epic, or more accurately the Noah Epic is the Gilgamesh Epic. Tablets recording to the Gilgamesh were dated well beyond any references to Israelites. Not to mention that Gilgamesh was stolen and turned into Enuma Elish, which is itself older then the Jewish story of Genesis. Tablets of both Elish and Gilgamesh were found in the areas the Israelites inhabited before any record of Jewish Genesis was found.

jyoshu

The Gilgamesh Epic is the Noah epic, or more accurately the Noah Epic is the Gilgamesh Epic. Tablets recording to the Gilgamesh were dated well beyond any references to Israelites. Not to mention that Gilgamesh was stolen and turned into Enuma Elish, which is itself older then the Jewish story of Genesis. Tablets of both Elish and Gilgamesh were found in the areas the Israelites inhabited before any record of Jewish Genesis was found. 

 
 But you're comparing the dating of writing material to the age of an oral tradition, which effectively can't be done. We really don't know which predates the other--all we KNOW is that older tablets of the Gilgamesh one were found. That is perfectly consistent with the fact that semitic cultures carried their myths orally, while Babylonian ones wrote it down. It doesn't speak to which one is older. You may be surprised that research has showed there to be at least somewhere in the neighborhood of 80,000 epic flood myths around the world. They are VERY common in cultural histories. Even the American Indians had similar flood myths. 
 
 
Huh? How does dating of tablets at least a 1000 years before the first record of Jewish Genesis not factually prove that Gilgamesh is older?

 
 Because, again, you're dating an object (tablets) against oral tradition (or at least what BEGAN as oral tradition). We have no idea how far back the Hebrew version goes. Really, it is possible that Gilgamesh goes back further than the tablets we have found as well! So the bottom line is that we just don't know.

 Frankly, genesis is nothing more then a story to explain to ignorant, nomadic Israelites of how the world started. It's suppose to be simple, these people don't know jack about science and quite frankly, are concerned with two things: Finding their next meal and not being killed/enslaved by Egyptians. Telling them how it actually happened would be beyond futile.

We have tablets of Gilgamesh that existed before the Israelites. How do you deal with this problem? 

 
 If you knew anything about Bible history, you would know that Noah lived long before the Israelites, who were called that after Jacob was named Israel. Of course Jacob was a descendant of Noah, as were your Gilgamesh writers. Get the picture?
 
 
 
 
 So you're saying that the tablets that predate the Israelites are in fact written by people who had magical time machines who wrote them after the Israelites and then warped them back in time?
 
 STAND UP COMEDY!

jyoshu

 Then that only muddies the whole thing even more so. We know that much LESS which came first.
 
 
The bigger point is, we have evidence that the Epic was around before the Israelites, who later turned into the Jews.

 
 No, we have found tablets that existed before the Israelites, as a settled nation. That doesn't automatically mean the Gilgamesh epic was earlier than the Noah story, or that the Noah account wasn't around long earlier.
 
 
So without anyone to carry around a oral jewish tradition, there's not much of argument now is there? The most complete version of Gilgamesh is from the 7th century BC library of a old ruler, while Gilgamesh himself is believed to be living somewhere around the 3rd millennium BC. I'm pretty damn sure that's before any Israelites were walking around.

 
 Why on earth do you think that matters??? "Israelites" weren't around in the Noah story either! The question isn't whether "Israelites" were around; the question is whether or not the Noah story was around! (which is in not way dependent on whether Israel was an organized cuture/nation yet.) What you don't seem to understand is that just because one account was found to be early doesn't mean the other was automatically LATER. Semitic people moved around a lot--the Noah account very well could have originated elsewhere. You seem intent on tying it to the area, but with Semitic people of the time, that's unrealistic.
 
 
There are litterally thousands of flood beliefs in this world.

 
 Er, I think I just said that.
 
 
What creationists omit is that very, very, very few of these stories have any similarities outside of water. Just because alot of cultures had a flood story doesn't mean a global flood happened.

 
 Irrelevant--I never said they were that similar. You're jumping to conclusions here; I'm not arguing for the legitimacy of a global flood here; I'm trying to get you to realize that we really can't KNOW for sure if the Gilgamesh epic predates the Noah account.
 
 
If there are no people speaking hebrew at the time of the oldest dated story, there's no argument ... 

 
 Your premise is based on the idea that the Noah story had to have started out in Hebrew. You don't know that. The only thing we have to tie it to Hebrew is what we have of it written down, and since it very well could have existed in oral tradition much earlier, who knows? Again you're pitting oral tradition against written, here. You have to realize that Genesis is probably a compilation of various stories that were going on for awhile. Anyone who says they KNOW the Gilgamesh epic is older than the Noah epic is either lying, kidding themselves, or misrepresenting the situation. It MAY be older, but the only thing we KNOW is that what we have FOUND is older. For all we know the Noah story, in oral form being passed down, may predate the "Israelites" as well. There are just too many unanswered questions.
obvious_child

Then that only muddies the whole thing even more so. We know that much LESS which came first.

 
 Not really. We know the oldest version of the tablets existed before the Israelites. As the tradition existed well before the tablets in a oral tradition it seems somewhat logical that it would be older. If the tablets that recorded the oral tradition are older then the earliest records of the Israelites, why we are even discussing this? 
 
 
No, we have found tablets that existed before the Israelites, as a settled nation. That doesn't automatically mean the Gilgamesh epic was earlier than the Noah story, or that the Noah account wasn't around long earlier.

 
 Israelites is a term for the nomadic people that turned into the Jewish Tribes which eventually turned into the Kingdoms of Israel. You're confusing Jews with Israelites. Not the same thing. 
 
 
Why on earth do you think that matters??? "Israelites" weren't around in the Noah story either! The question isn't whether "Israelites" were around; the question is whether or not the Noah story was around!

 
 My point is that the Israelites adopted a story from another culture about the flood. If the Israelites didn't exist before Gilgamesh was recorded, that would suggest that they didn't come up with the flood story but adopted it. 
 
 
What you don't seem to understand is that just because one account was found to be early doesn't mean the other was automatically LATER.

 
 What you don't seem to understand is that if one account is found to be dated before any evidence of the existance of another group who believed something similar, that is it very likely that the first account is older. 
 
 
Semitic people moved around a lot--the Noah account very well could have originated elsewhere. You seem intent on tying it to the area, but with Semitic people of the time, that's unrealistic.

 
 Considering that that is the only area in the world that has such a flood story, it would seem logical to tie the argument there. I already commented that your statement on thousands of flood stories share virtually nothing in common. The first recorded tablets of the flood came from region above where the Akkadian Empire existed. Then the second batch of findings was in the Akkadian. Then the third batch was in Palestian. As we know there was extensive trade between the regions, logically we can point out as time progresses that the story traveled with the trade routes from its origin to Palestian where it was adopted by the Israelites who put it into the Torah. 
 
 
Irrelevant--I never said they were that similar.

 
 It was implied, and your statement was identical to creationists arguments that argue the flood was true. 
 
 
I'm trying to get you to realize that we really can't KNOW for sure if the Gilgamesh epic predates the Noah account.

 
 We can't know anything for sure from quantum physics to our own existance. What we can look at is the historical data and make conclusions and that data would suggest that the flood story moved down into Palestian and was adopted by the Israelites. Not that the Israelites came up with it. 
 
 
Your premise is based on the idea that the Noah story had to have started out in Hebrew.

 
 No, my premise is the idea that the flood story started out in whatever dilect was spoken in what today is Northern Iraq, North West Iran, South East Turkey and North East Syria. 
 
 
You don't know that.

 
 We don't know anything. Stop using the skeptic argument. 
 
 
The only thing we have to tie it to Hebrew is what we have of it written down, and since it very well could have existed in oral tradition much earlier, who knows?

 
 It also could have existed for thousands of years prior to being written down on the tablets in oral form as well. The empire in which Gilgamesh was found existed well before any existance of the Israelites. How you keep thinking that such data is irrevelant is borderline delusional. 
 
 
Again you're pitting oral tradition against written, here.

 
 No, I'm pitting a old oral tradition that was later transfered to tablet aganist another oral and written tradition. What you seem to be deliberately ignoring is where recorded information was found, the travel and trade patterns and the fact that the oldest tablets existed before any evidence of the israelites. If someone does not exist, can they have a tradition older then themselves?
 
 Why can't you see this? Unlike EZ, you're not a idiot.
 
 
You have to realize that Genesis is probably a compilation of various stories that were going on for awhile.

 
 That's my subtle point.
 
 
Anyone who says they KNOW the Gilgamesh epic is older than the Noah epic is either lying, kidding themselves, or misrepresenting the situation. It MAY be older, but the only thing we KNOW is that what we have FOUND is older. For all we know the Noah story, in oral form being passed down, may predate the "Israelites" as well. There are just too many unanswered questions.

 
 It bothers me you rely almost entirely upon the skeptic's argument in order to avoid discussing historical matters. 
 
 We cannot 'know' anything for sure. What we can do is look at the data, I'm trying, you're clearly trying to avoid just that.
jyoshu

Not really. We know the oldest version of the tablets existed before the Israelites. As the tradition existed well before the tablets in a oral tradition it seems somewhat logical that it would be older. If the tablets that recorded the oral tradition are older then the earliest records of the Israelites, why we are even discussing this? 

 
 Because when you are talking about something in antiquity and oral tradition, it is not so cut and dry as dealing with modern, recorded history. 
 
 
Israelites is a term for the nomadic people that turned into the Jewish Tribes which eventually turned into the Kingdoms of Israel. You're confusing Jews with Israelites. Not the same thing. 

 
 It doesn't matter, the story may still be older than that.
 
 
My point is that the Israelites adopted a story from another culture about the flood. If the Israelites didn't exist before Gilgamesh was recorded, that would suggest that they didn't come up with the flood story but adopted it. 

 
 That's a theory, but it's certainly not a given. The Israelites (as a nomadic people) may very well HAVE existed at the time of Gilgamesh's 'recording.'
 
 
We don't know anything. Stop using the skeptic argument. 
 
 It bothers me you rely almost entirely upon the skeptic's argument in order to avoid discussing historical matters. 
 
 We cannot 'know' anything for sure. What we can do is look at the data, I'm trying, you're clearly trying to avoid just that.

 
 But particularly we can't know THIS, because it's a matter of antiquity and before recorded history. This is much more than just the same sort of 'skeptics argument' that could be applied to anything. It may indeed 'bother' you, but when you are dealing with ancient history, it always needs to be approached from the standpoint that there are no givens with things like this. You want to brush this off as irrelevant calling it the "skeptics argument" but you CAN'T deal with antiquity without it. When you're using your point to try to disprove something, you just can't state as fact what you don't know to be fact. I'm more than willing to discuss historical matters, I just am not willing to go along with you that we know for a fact that Gilgamesh came earlier. We don't. When people such as yourself sometimes try to use this to disprove the legitimacy of the Noah story, the "skeptics argument" becomes very relevant. Unless we were able to have proof about a oral tradition (which is basically impossible) we'll never really know for CERTAIN which came first.

Because when you are talking about something in antiquity and oral tradition, it is not so cut and dry as dealing with modern, recorded history.

As Moses was born long after the dating of some of the tablets we run into a problem. Oral tradition or not, if the guy who wrote the Torah as revealed by the Jewish God didn't exist before the existance of the Gilgamesh tablets, well, that's pretty much open shut.

 No, we can't. We don't know if the Noah account was a rewriting of an earlier account or not--we have no idea how far back the Noahic story goes in oral tradition. 
 
 
The Flood story is false independent of human history. There are enough scientific problems with it in the fossil record and basic chemistry to prove it's bull. I'm not arguing that it's false here (there are other threads for that), merely that it is not of Israelite origin.

 Give it up, Jyoshu.

 
 Give it up yourself. This "analogy" is, well, pretty ridiculous on your part. We're discussing ancient history that is in large part dependent on oral tradition, not modern recorded history which can be verified even by people still alive today. If you think ancient history that far back is so cut and dry that you can know for certain an account didn't exist orally long before it was written (during a time of oral tradition), you should be presenting your views and your reasons to every historical journal there is. You're talking in terms of abandoning some pretty darn fundamental understanding in terms of the way ancient history worked.

The issue of whether Moses write the Pentateuch is independent of whether the Noah story goes farther back. Moses may not have written/compiled the 1st 5 books, or he may. He may have written the Noahic account from the oral account--more than likely he did. he wouldn't have had to exist before then.

 
 Depends how and if you accept the Jewish Scholar's view on the Torah. If you follow their arguments, Yaweh divined the Torah to Moses. No, we can't. We don't know if the Noah account was a rewriting of an earlier account or not--we have no idea how far back the Noahic story goes in oral tradition.

 
 Or if goes back at all. Alright, let's assume the Israelite nomads had the first flood story. Given how they travelled huge areas, why do we have no records of such similar stories in those areas? If it was a truly old oral tradition, it would have difussed into the areas they wandered and eventually would have been recorded. Israelites were often slaves to other civilizations. Why do we have no records of the oral traditions from those civilizations? We are dealing with a alleged old oral tradition that left no mark anywhere else but the Torah despite huge diasporas of Isralites all over the region. This seem hugely suspicious. Granted, I'll give you we cannot know for certain (or anything) but given the historical evidence, there's not alot of crediblity towards the idea the Noah version was the first version.
 
 
But you can't. All you can prove is that what has been found (in terms of tablets) is older.

 
 But given the lack of any evidence that the oral tradition by the Israelites was indeed older, it does seem likely. Israelites were everywhere in the area. Why is there no record of this tradition, especially in civilizations like Early Egypt and Babyloan which wrote huge amounts of things about what they did down?
peteratwar

Wonderful how arguments can develop about events which happened probably in the dawn of history remembered as folk memories but about which there is no precise knowledge.
 
 So you argue about something of which you have no direct knowledge with evidence (?) which at the least is uncertain.
 
 One can only say that oral/folk traditions may get distorted over the millenia but usually recall some catastrophic event. You then distort this by citing records which were themselves probably written millenia or centuries after the event using dating ideas which are no more than theories.
 
 Mind you it would be lovely to know what really happened

 Ever heard of the good old "I caught a fish this big" story, and others similar to it? That's what happened here. It is perfectly logical to assume that someone witnessed a large flood, and over time it all got blown out of proportion and became the ludicroud claim of the entire world flooding and a man making a boat (which is pretty much incapable of actually floating and surviving a flood) and carrying two of every animal. With each telling of a story, things are changed and added and exaggerated - that's just common sense.
